questions.question: Which cells are responsible for secreting the cuticle in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Epithelial cells covering the body and interfacial cells lining major openings.

questions.question: How does the cuticle of C. elegans change with each larval stage?

answers.ans: It differs in surface protein expression, layer number, relative thickness, and composition.
It remains the same throughout all stages.

questions.question: What is the approximate thickness of the adult C. elegans cuticle?
Which collagen localizes to the furrows in all stages of C. elegans?
What is the primary structural component of the C. elegans cuticle?
What is the function of the pharyngeal cuticle in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It lines the lumen and forms specialized structures like flaps, sieve, and grinder.
It provides structural support to the intestine.

questions.question: Which cells contribute to the secretion of the pharyngeal cuticle?
What is the role of the grinder in the C. elegans pharynx?

answers.ans: It grinds food particles before they enter the intestine.
It regulates the flow of food from the pharynx to the intestine.
It traps bacteria in the pharynx.

questions.question: How does the pharyngeal nervous system affect the pumping action in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It regulates the intrinsic myogenic activity of the pharynx.
It directly controls the contraction of body wall muscles.
It inhibits the pharyngeal pumping in the presence of food.
It has no effect on the pharyngeal pumping.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the marginal cells in the C. elegans pharynx?

answers.ans: They provide structural reinforcement to the pharynx.
They regulate the flow of food into the intestine.

questions.question: Which neurons are responsible for regulating the pumping rate of the pharynx in C. elegans?

answers.ans: MC, M2, and M4 motor neurons

questions.question: What is the role of the pharyngeal-intestinal valve in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It acts as a passively open channel between the pharynx and intestine.
It actively regulates the flow of food into the intestine.
It secretes digestive enzymes into the intestine.
It prevents backflow of intestinal contents into the pharynx.

questions.question: How does the pharyngeal cuticle differ from the body cuticle in C. elegans?

answers.ans: The pharyngeal cuticle shows no layers and has specialized structures.
The pharyngeal cuticle is thicker and more rigid.
The pharyngeal cuticle is composed of multiple layers.
The pharyngeal cuticle is more permeable to nutrients.

questions.question: What is the function of the pharyngeal sieve in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It traps bacteria just posterior of the metacorpus.
It regulates the flow of food into the intestine.
It provides structural support to the pharynx.

questions.question: Which cells are involved in the secretion of the pharyngeal cuticle during the lethargus period?
What is the primary function of the intestine in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Digestion of food, absorption of nutrients, and synthesis of macromolecules.
Secretion of digestive enzymes into the pharynx.

questions.question: How is the intestine of C. elegans anchored within the body?

answers.ans: It is anchored to the pharyngeal and rectal valves.
It is directly attached to the body wall.
It is suspended by muscular attachments.
It is free-floating within the body cavity.

questions.question: What is the role of the microvilli in the C. elegans intestine?

answers.ans: They form a brush border for nutrient absorption.
They provide structural support to the intestine.
They regulate the flow of food into the intestine.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the coelomocytes in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Absorption and concentration of soluble materials

questions.question: How many coelomocytes are present in an adult C. elegans hermaphrodite?
Which innexin gene is expressed only in the GABAergic inhibitory motor neuron classes, DD and VD, in C. elegans?
What is the role of the M mesoblast in C. elegans development?

answers.ans: Responsible for all nongonadal mesoderm formation during post-embryonic development

questions.question: What is the primary structural difference between innexin-based channels in C. elegans and connexin-based channels in vertebrates?

answers.ans: Innexin channels in C. elegans often involve more subunits per hemichannel
Innexin channels are larger in diameter
Connexin channels have fewer subunits per hemichannel
Innexin channels are exclusively found in the nervous system

questions.question: What is the origin of the intestine in C. elegans during development?
Which cells in C. elegans are responsible for the muscular pumping and peristalsis of the pharynx?
What is the primary function of gap junctions in the pharyngeal muscles of C. elegans?

answers.ans: Facilitate rapid radial contractions during feeding

questions.question: How many innexin genes are encoded in the C. elegans genome?
What is the primary function of the pharyngeal neurons in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Influence the pharynx to change from one mode of action to the next

questions.question: Which cells in C. elegans are suggested to serve immune, scavenging, and hepatic functions?
What is the primary role of the enteric muscles in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Act on the intestine and rectal valve

questions.question: What is the primary structural feature of the alimentary system in C. elegans?

answers.ans: A separate epithelial tube running inside the cylindrical body wall

questions.question: Which innexin gene is expressed mostly in glial cells in C. elegans?
What is the primary function of the gap junctions in the excretory canal cell of C. elegans?

answers.ans: Permit the transfer of small molecules or fluid between tissues

questions.question: Which neurons in C. elegans are linked by gap junctions to the GLR support cells in the head?
What is the primary role of the somatic sheath cells in the gonad of C. elegans?

answers.ans: Squeeze on the germline to force it into a cylindrical shape

questions.question: Which innexin gene is associated with the proper maturation of the eggshell in C. elegans?
What is the primary function of the gap junctions in the bodywall muscles of C. elegans?

answers.ans: Conduct action potentials from head to tail or vice versa

questions.question: What is the primary reason Sydney Brenner chose C. elegans as a model organism?

answers.ans: Its simplicity and power of prokaryotic genetics.
Its large size and complex anatomy.
Its ability to survive extreme temperatures.

questions.question: What is the approximate length of an adult C. elegans?
What is the frequency of male C. elegans in a population?
What is the primary food source for C. elegans in laboratory settings?
What is the significance of the C. elegans genome being the first multicellular organism to be sequenced?

answers.ans: It provided a basis for rich comparative genomics studies.
It proved C. elegans could survive in space.
It showed C. elegans could photosynthesize.
It demonstrated C. elegans' ability to regenerate limbs.

questions.question: What is the role of the hermaphrodite's spermatheca in C. elegans?
What is the function of the dauer larva stage in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It is a dispersal form that can survive harsh conditions.
It is a stage for rapid growth.
It is a stage for photosynthesis.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of C. elegans' transparency for researchers?

answers.ans: It allows visualization of individual cells and subcellular details.
It makes them invisible to predators.
It enables them to absorb more sunlight.
It allows them to camouflage in their environment.

questions.question: What is the primary method of genetic manipulation used in C. elegans research?
What is the significance of the invariant cell lineage in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It allows researchers to track the fate of every cell from fertilization to adulthood.
It enables C. elegans to regenerate lost limbs.
It allows C. elegans to change sex.
It enables C. elegans to survive without food.

questions.question: What is the primary neurotransmitter used by C. elegans neurons?
What is the function of the cuticle in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It provides a protective layer and determines body shape.

questions.question: What is the primary reason C. elegans is used as a model organism in neurobiology?

answers.ans: Its simple and well-mapped nervous system.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of using RNA interference (RNAi) in C. elegans research?

answers.ans: It allows systematic interrogation of gene function.
It enables C. elegans to fly.
It allows C. elegans to change color.
It enables C. elegans to grow larger.

questions.question: What is the primary role of the LIN-12/Notch signaling pathway in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It is involved in vulval development.

questions.question: What is the significance of the C. elegans connectome?

answers.ans: It is the most mature effort to map synaptic contacts in a nervous system.
It shows C. elegans can survive in space.
It proves C. elegans can regenerate limbs.
It demonstrates C. elegans' ability to photosynthesize.

questions.question: What is the primary method used to observe C. elegans in the laboratory?
What is the primary advantage of C. elegans' rapid life cycle for researchers?

answers.ans: It allows quick generation of experimental data.
It enables them to live longer.
It allows them to survive without food.
It enables them to grow larger.

questions.question: What is the primary reason C. elegans is considered a powerful model for eukaryotic genetic studies?

answers.ans: Its ability to self-fertilize and produce large numbers of offspring.

questions.question: What is the cell lineage of the neuron ADAL in C. elegans?
Which type of neuron is ADER in C. elegans?
What is the function of the AQR neuron in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Basal body, not part of a sensillum, projects into ring
Innervates dorsal muscles, no ventral counterpart

questions.question: Which neuron has the cell lineage AB plppaappa in C. elegans?
What type of neuron is AIBL in C. elegans?
What is the cell lineage of the neuron AIML in C. elegans?
Which neuron is described as a "Ring interneuron" in C. elegans?
What is the function of the neuron ALA in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Sends processes laterally and along dorsal cord
Innervates dorsal muscles, no ventral counterpart

questions.question: What is the cell lineage of the neuron ALML in C. elegans?
Which neuron is associated with the cell lineage AB plapappppap in C. elegans?
What type of neuron is AS1 in C. elegans?
What is the cell lineage of the neuron AS10 in C. elegans?
Which neuron in C. elegans is described as having a "single ciliated ending"?
What is the cell lineage of the neuron ASGL in C. elegans?
Which neuron is described as "nociceptive" in C. elegans?
What is the cell lineage of the neuron AIAL in C. elegans?
Which neuron is described as "Amphid-associated Unknown Receptor" in C. elegans?
What is the cell lineage of the neuron AVAL in C. elegans?
Which neuron is described as a "Ventral cord interneuron" in C. elegans?
